prior_works.title: Learning Fair Representations
prior_works.authors: Rich Zemel, Yu Wu, Kevin Swersky, Toniann Pitassi, Cynthia Dwork
prior_works.role: Foundational fair representation framework establishing the fairness–utility trade-off
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the notion of fair representations and the intrinsic accuracy–fairness Pareto trade-off that this paper seeks to compute efficiently, providing the baseline paradigm the new method strategically avoids training.

prior_works.title: Censoring Representations with an Adversary
prior_works.role: Adversarial learning approach to fair representations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed how to remove sensitive information via adversarial training, a class of complex fair-representation models that the present work replaces with a discrete reduction grounded in structural theory.

prior_works.title: Equality of Opportunity in Supervised Learning
prior_works.authors: Moritz Hardt, Eric Price, Nati Srebro
prior_works.role: Structural characterization of optimal fair classifiers via ROC geometry and randomized thresholding
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Characterized optimal solutions for equalized-odds post-processing as group-specific thresholds and randomization on ROC convex hulls, directly informing this paper’s structural properties and discrete reduction for Pareto-front computation.

prior_works.title: Fairness Beyond Disparate Treatment and Disparate Impact
prior_works.authors: Muhammad Bilal Zafar, Isabel Valera, Manuel Gomez-Rodriguez, Krishna P. Gummadi
prior_works.role: Convex surrogate formulation of fairness constraints enabling efficient trade-off optimization
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated that fairness–accuracy trade-offs can be optimized via convex surrogates, motivating the present work’s compact optimization viewpoint and its use of standard optimization machinery.

prior_works.title: A Reductions Approach to Fair Classification
prior_works.authors: Alekh Agarwal, Alina Beygelzimer, Miroslav Dudík, John Langford, Hanna Wallach
prior_works.role: Reduction of constrained fair learning to cost-sensitive classification
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided a principled reduction framework for fair classification, inspiring this paper’s reduction of Pareto-front computation to a compact discrete problem that can be solved efficiently.

prior_works.title: The Cost of Fairness in Binary Classification
prior_works.authors: Aditya Krishna Menon, Robert C. Williamson
prior_works.role: Theoretical analysis of accuracy–fairness trade-offs and optimal decision rules
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Analyzed the geometry of fairness constraints and showed optimality of threshold-based rules under various notions, supporting this paper’s derivation of structural properties that enable exact Pareto-front computation.

prior_works.title: The Concave-Convex Procedure (CCCP)
prior_works.role: General-purpose algorithm for solving difference-of-convex programs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the off-the-shelf concave–convex optimization method leveraged to efficiently solve the compact approximating problems that arise from the paper’s discrete reduction.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core innovation—computing the optimal fairness–performance Pareto front without training complex models—emerges from unifying structural insights about optimal fair decisions with reductionist optimization techniques. Early representation-learning work by Zemel et al. established the fairness–utility trade-off and popularized fair representations, while adversarial approaches like Edwards and Storkey refined this paradigm but at the cost of heavy modeling. In contrast, Hardt et al. provided a geometric and probabilistic characterization of optimal fair classifiers via ROC convexification and group-specific thresholding, revealing discrete structure (thresholds and randomization) that directly suggests compact representations of the trade-off surface. Menon and Williamson further formalized the “price of fairness,” proving threshold optimality under various constraints and clarifying the geometry of Pareto-optimal solutions. On the algorithmic side, Zafar et al. and Agarwal et al. showed that fairness-constrained learning can be reframed as convex or cost-sensitive optimization, legitimizing reductions that trade modeling complexity for principled optimization. Building on these, the present paper derives structural properties of optimal fair representations and classifiers that reduce Pareto-front computation to a compact discrete problem, then solves the resulting difference-of-convex formulations efficiently using CCCP (Yuille and Rangarajan). The synthesis yields an end-to-end methodology that bypasses training complex fair-representation models while delivering exact, efficiently computable Pareto fronts for both representations and classifiers.
